Issues.Title: Clean up DpiHelper
Issues.Body:
This change cleans up the DpiHelper by clarifying terminology, making behavior more consistent, and fixing a number of issues.

- Rename DpiHelper to ScaleHelper
- Use OS terms
- Use more descriptive naming
- Make scaling actions a no-op if scaling to 100% and just call ScaleHelper by default
- Encapsulate logical default values to avoid accidental unscaled use
- Keep parking window tracking within Application
- Remove System.Window.Forms dependency on SystemEvents
- Remove unreachable code from VsPropertyGrid
- Fixes the Application default font scaling.
- Update some comments (MonthCalendar comments were still in Java)

Most controls that scale use the initial System DPI and don't do any further scaling.

The idea here is that being explicit about what we're scaling to makes things clearer. Always using the ScaleHelper, reducing the caching of scaled values, and factoring the scaling together will make understanding the current behavior easier and make implementing dynamic scaling easier.

DockEditor.DockUI is an example where understanding class state is significantly easier.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Clean up DpiHelper" (#10434)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.0-alpha.1.23576.1

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, Narrator can announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control in 8.0/7.0
For the 9.0, have the new change was introduced by PR: #10243 which caused this issue.

### Issue description

Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control in 9.0

### Steps to reproduce

**Reproduce steps:**
1. Create .NET Core winforms project targeting 9.0.
2. Add DataGridView control to the Form1.cs[Design] with some columns.
3. Build and run the project.
4. Launch the Narrator tool, and focus on first row.
5. Input some text on the textbox cell.
6. Press the Down keyboard to move the new added row.
7. Observe the results.

**Actual Results:**
After steps #5, the Narrator announce "Row 2 is added"
After steps #6, the Narrator announce  "Row 3, Column1 Row 3, Not sorted......."
![ActualBehaviour](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/44fabe28-386e-4809-9460-2604417cee52)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/1878fcf6-743f-40e1-a949-a84ec349a42a)

**Expected Results:**
After steps #5, the Narrator announce the new added row correctly
![80Behaviour](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/6210ea42-57b4-4855-8e38-ec790bd48699)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/efeee649-8c9b-4513-b84b-639e1bfbdbc7)

**More info:**
After steps #6. continue input some text on the new added new row, the Narrator always announce that" **Row 1, Editing Control, edit, <say-as interpret-as="spell">t</say-as>, Row Header Row 1, Row** <say-as interpret-as="cardinal">1</say-as> of <say-as interpret-as="cardinal">4</say-as> "
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/eefd21a1-7ed6-40ce-8347-792e80fc750f)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator can't announce the new added row correctly for DataGrridView control" (#10428)

Issues.Title: System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream) can not suppport .NET8
Issues.Body:
### Environment

OS: Microsoft Windows Version 22H2 (OS Build 19045.3570)
VisualStudio 2022: Version 17.8.2


### .NET version

.NET SDK:Version 8.0.100
Arch: X64(also can reproduce in other Arch)

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

The serialization works well in .NET Framework 4.8
A sample project is provided.

### Issue description

System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream); 

> https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.componentmodel.design.serialization.serializationstore?view=net-7.0

The serialization works well in .NET Framework 4.8, but it shows 'platform not support' exception after we update to .NET8 SDK.

### Steps to reproduce

Call System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.SerializationStore.Save(Stream stream) function directly  to save a user control in .NET8
[WinFormsNET8.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13553852/WinFormsNET8.zip)

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/39147380/57416b82-0edb-409d-bdb3-e80110c5f75b)

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/39147380/b8291438-c30c-4a1a-b112-93b20e75b349)


### Diagnostics

```text
We notice that, this function is support in .NET8 according to MSDN, but it throw 'platform not support' exception' when we call it.

> https://learn.microsoft.com/zh-cn/dotnet/api/system.componentmodel.design.serialization.serializationstore?view=net-8.0
```

Issues.Title: ErrorProvider HasErrors returns incorrect value after clearing an error
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The implementation of #5912 does not take into account clearing an individual error. The documentation for ErrorProvider.SetError states for the value "The error description string, or null or Empty to remove the error."

So HasErrors returns an incorrect value if SetError has ever been used, even if there is now no error.

### Steps to reproduce

Basic application logic is
  SetError(control, "Some error");
  _HasErrors should be true at this point_
  SetError(control, null);
  _HasErrors should be **false** at this point_
  
Given that GetError also creates an entry in _items with a null error the following will also cause incorrect results:
  _ = GetError(control);
  _HasErrors should be **false** at this point_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ErrorProvider HasErrors returns incorrect value after clearing an error" (#10424)

Issues.Title: More uses of ArgumentOutOfRangeException throw helpers
Issues.Body:
Related: #9726

So far I left alone quite a few instances of manual `ArgumentOutOfRangeException` creation and throwing. Those are the ones in property setter.

Their error messages mention both the `value` parameter and the name of the propery itself. I we want to get rid of custom error messages, we need to take care of them, but if we do so we have to choose between the two names.

So far in this PR I only touched two properties to show our options:

1. Use `value` in the error message
2. Use the property name in the error message
3. Do nothing

Once a decision has been made, I'll use this PR to enforce it across codebase. Then we will be in a position to close the issue above

@lonitra 

<!-- ## Proposed changes

-->

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Low: some error messages will change

Issues.Title: HDPI: Position of a Modal-Form (and Modeless) is not centered to parent
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK:
Version: 7.0.404
Commit: 22f221a24c

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

The behaviour on .NET 6 is difference to .NET 7, but also not correct.

### Issue description

I have a Form that is opened as Modal (.ShowDialog()) with `StartPosition = FormStartPosition.CenterParent;`
But on my Secondary-Screen with 100% scaling, the Modal Dialog is not centered to it's parent. But a Modeless Dialog (.Show()) is centered!

On my Main-Screen with 125% scaling, the Modal Dialog is correctly centered, but the Modeless Dialog is not centered.

However if I call `CenterToParent();` in Load-Event of the Form, the form is correctly centered.

![Screenshot (74)](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/87719952/95605061-9064-446b-a8af-e2e346b19023)

![Screenshot (76)](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/87719952/f87d5baa-130c-4f10-b91d-e73bfa8510b5)

The fix of issue [#5729](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/5729) seems not handle this case.


In .NET Framework 4.7.2 it seems that Modless Dialogs never centered.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a new Default .NET Winforms App.

Setup the DpiAwareness Mode in Main()-Method

`Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.PerMonitorV2);`


Create a second Form that is called from the Mainform.
Second Form is set to `StartPosition = FormStartPosition.CenterParent;`

``` 
...
   // Show as Modal Dialog
    DialogForm dialogForm = new DialogForm();
    dialogForm.ShowDialog(this);           

...

  // Show as Modeless Dialog
    Form dialogForm = new DialogForm();
    dialogForm.Show(this);

...
```

[Dialog_CenterParent.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13546509/Dialog_CenterParent.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "HDPI: Position of a Modal-Form (and Modeless) is not centered to parent" (#10422)

Issues.Title: Convert Multiple AccessibleObject Interfaces to Cswin32
Issues.Body:
Related: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/9795

Converts various interfaces on AccessibleObject to Cswin32 and updates correspondings tests. The conversions are separated by commits.

Also introduce `IComInterface<T>` to bound COM structs to their COM interfaces. Currently this is used for the purposes of new method `ComSafeArrayScope.CreateFromInterfaceArray` in order to generically go from COM interface [] -> SafeArray of COM pointers, but may be useful for other purposes as we continue making WinForms trimmable. Tests are also added around this.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10407)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Convert Multiple AccessibleObject Interfaces to Cswin32" (#10407)

Issues.Title: Migrate to the Locker GitHub action for locking closed/stale issues/PRs
Issues.Body:
This migrates away from the FabricBot implementation of a scheduled search over closed issues and adopts the [Locker](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-github-triage-actions/?tab=readme-ov-file#locker) GitHub action authored by the VS Code team.

The updated fabricbot.json was generated via https://github.com/dotnet/fabricbot-config/pull/83. The workflow file was implemented and tested at https://github.com/dotnet/fabricbot-config/blob/main/.github/workflows/locker.yml.

Since this workflow uses the actions/checkout action, we need to ensure the following GitHub Actions settings are enabled:

1. Allow enterprise, and select non-enterprise, actions and reusable workflows
2. Allow actions created by GitHub

/cc @wtgodbe

Issues.Title: Images added as a resource inaccessible from controls
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2022 (64-bit) - Current
Version 17.8.0

### .NET version

8.0.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Unknown

### Issue description

Attempting to add an image to a project from the Resources.resx designer, does not allow those images to be used by controls (such as a pictureBox), even though they are 'addable' from such controls, and even preview correctly.

Issue is seen with a .NET 8, WinForms C# project.

### Steps to reproduce

1. In solution explorer, right click on Properties > Resources.resx > Open
2. Change Icons dropdown to Images
3. Add Resource > Add Existing file
4. Navigate to where the image is and select the image
5. In the newly added images Properties, leave Persistence as 'Linked at compile time'
6. In the newly added resource Properties (Solution explorer > Project >Resources > new resource), leave these as default (build action: none)
7. Open the designer to a form with a pictureBox
8. In the properties of said pictureBox, go to Image to select a resource. The newly added resource should be visible inside 'Project resource file'
9. Select this resource
10. It should now appear in the designer successfully, great!
11. Build the solution - now it fails. 

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	CS0117	'Resources' does not contain a definition for 'images'

You'll note that the newly added resource's build action has defaulted to 'Content' from 'None'. Try changing this to 'Embedded Resource' instead, the build still fails. Even if changing the Resources persistence to 'Embedded in .resx'.

Alternatively............. one can import the resource from the pictureBox directly, but the result is the same.

One thing, and perhaps the most important to note - is this is a project that was migrated from .NET framework, to .NET using the Visual Studio .NET Upgrade Assistant.




### Diagnostics

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Images added as a resource inaccessible from controls" (#10412)

Issues.Title: HelpProvider unable to load DLL 'htmlhelp.dll' or one of its dependencies
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0.100-alpha.1.23580.4

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it works in .NET 8.0/7.0/6.0. It's a regression issue in .NET 9.0.

### Issue description

The 'Unable to load DLL 'htmlhelp.dll' or one of its dependencies' exception occurs when invoke HelpProvider in runtime.

**The behavior for .NET 9.0:**
![9 0-result](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/6289dfa7-b5c6-4306-b780-b590b9c7ffcc)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/e255e2df-7954-4934-adf7-fced235a394e

**The behavior for .NET 8.0 or .NET Framework:**

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/45864985/9e6df513-d035-4749-bfae-ed86cc30d900



### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the [HelpProvider-TestApp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/13521770/HelpProvider-TestApp.zip) project.
2. Build and run project.
3. Click the **?** icon in the upper right corner in form.
4. Then click the textbox under **Address:**.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "HelpProvider unable to load DLL 'htmlhelp.dll' or one of its dependencies" (#10410)

Issues.Title: WinForms TabControl does not expose TabItem controls to UIAutomation
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, I believe it was working in .NET 6.

### Issue description

For a WinForms TabControl, the tab page is exposed through UIAutomation but the TabItem controls are missing so there is no way for automations to switch between tabs.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a WinForms app. Add a TabControl. By default it will have to pages. Run it. Walk the tree of the application. Tab page is there but no TabItem controls.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms TabControl does not expose TabItem controls to UIAutomation" (#10408)
